) c) to ensure that IRS understand why maiden names and names previously used by the employee, such as birth maiden names, names from prior marriages, or previously used legal names, must not be IRS pseudonyms as they do not adequately protect an employee’s identity as they could be back to the IRS employee thereby compromising his or her safety and security. IRM
, Program Management and Review - Retitled subsection from “Program Management” to “Program Management and Review” to comply with IRM Internal Control Component requirements. IRM

IRM 10.5.7.4, Requesting an IRS Pseudonym - IPU 22U0712, Name Requirements When Requesting an IRS Pseudonym, issued 06-10-2022, clariﬁed (4) c) to ensure that IRS employees understand why maiden names and names previously used by the employee, such as birth maiden names, names from prior marriages, or previously used legal names, must not be used IRS pseudonyms as they do not adequately protect an employee’s identity as they could be traced back to the IRS employee thereby compromising his or her safety and security.
IRM 10.5.7.1.7, Related Resources - Added new (2) with links to the Pseudonyms page and the Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base Site. Subsequent paragraphs renumbered.
Throughout, reviewed and updated links and citations, website addresses, legal references and IRM references as necessary.
This IRM incorporates the following IRM Procedural Update (IPU): IPU 22U0712 dated 06/10/2022.
All IRS employees who hold IRS pseudonyms and IRS employees who submit a new request for the use of IRS pseudonym, and their managers.
Table of Contents
Text of Section 3706 of IRS RRA 98 from 26 USC 7804, dated July 22, 1998
by IRS Employees
page (

) Purpose: This IRM provides information, guidance, and procedures for all managers and employees on the process for requesting an IRS pseudonym, rescinding an IRS pseudonym, and using the IRS pseudonym after it’s obtained. (

) Audience: The provisions in this manual apply to all IRS employees who IRS pseudonyms and their managers and all IRS employees who submit a new request for the use of an IRS pseudonym and their managers. (

) Policy Owner: The Director, Privacy Policy and Compliance (PPC) is sible for the policy in this IRM. PPC is under the Office of Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD), which is under the Office of Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support (OS). (
) Program Owner: The Incident Management (IM) Office within the Office of Privacy Policy and Compliance (PPC) under PGLD is the program office re- sponsible for this IRM. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other to this IRM, email IM’s *Pseudonym mailbox. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Current and future IRS pseudonym holders and their managers. (

) Program Goals: The IRS is committed to the personal safety of its employees. The IRS Pseudonym Program provides the necessary and process to ensure an IRS pseudonym is assigned to IRS employees re- questing one for their personal safety and the prevention of harm or danger themselves and their families within ﬁve to ten business days of receiving pseudonym request. (
) Section
of the IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
USC
, dated July

, provides that any employee of the IRS may use an IRS pseudonym only if adequate justiﬁcation for the use of a pseudonym is provided by the employee, including protection of personal safety; and such use is approved by the employee’s supervisor before the pseudonym is used. ) The PGLD/IM Office is responsible for administering and managing IRS program requirements by ensuring IRS incidents involving the loss or theft of IRS and Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) assets containing Sensitive But Un- classiﬁed (SBU) data, including Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) and information; the loss or theft of physical and electronic documents that SBU data, including PII and tax information; and inadvertent unauthorized closures of SBU data, including PII and tax information, are investigated, analyzed and resolved. The PGLD/IM Office is also responsible for ing and managing the IRS Pseudonym Program. Speciﬁc responsibilities for the PGLD/IM Office, IRS employees, and IRS managers as they relate to the IRS Pseudonym Program are listed below.

The PGLD/IM Office is responsible for administering and managing IRS program requirements by ensuring IRS incidents involving the loss or theft of IRS and Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) assets containing Sensitive But Un

classiﬁed (SBU) data, including Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) and tax information; the loss or theft of physical and electronic documents that include SBU data, including PII and tax information; and inadvertent unauthorized dis
closures of SBU data, including PII and tax information, are investigated, analyzed and resolved. The PGLD/IM Office is also responsible for administer
ing and managing the IRS Pseudonym Program. Speciﬁc responsibilities for the PGLD/IM Office, IRS employees, and IRS managers as they relate to the IRS Pseudonym Program are listed below.
Privacy and Information (

) The PGLD Incident Management Office is responsible for: a. Managing the IRS Pseudonym Program in support of IRS employees who may, because of threats or potential threats to their personal need to work under the protection of an IRS pseudonym. b. Reviewing requests for IRS pseudonyms to ensure adequate is met as outlined in (
) and (
) of IRM

, Terms/Deﬁnitions/ Acronyms. c. Processing all requests for IRS pseudonyms received by the manager record within ﬁve to ten business days from receipt of the request. d. Maintaining a copy of the encrypted email documenting the approval of request for an IRS pseudonym. e. Managing and maintaining the official Pseudonym Master List (PML) all other related ﬁles where IRS pseudonym information will be stored. f. Ensuring that all information pertaining to IRS pseudonym holders is maintained in a secure manner consistent with IRS security and privacy policy requirements. g. Updating HR Connect to add IRS employee’s IRS pseudonym informa- tion. h. Updating Outlook (email) and Discovery Directory to display the IRS pseudonym and initiating the process to change the Smar

D to the pseudonym. i. Updating the PML each month to ensure that the information is correct and up-to-date. j. Processing all requests to withdraw from the IRS Pseudonym Program received by an IRS employee’s manager of record. See IRM
, Withdrawing from the IRS Pseudonym Program. Note: Visit the Pseudonyms page in the Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base Site for additional information about the IRS Pseudonym Program. (

) IRS employees are responsible for: a. Submitting his or her request for an IRS pseudonym to his or her immediate manager via encrypted email, or hard copy in a conﬁdential envelope. b. Following all request requirements as outlined in IRM

, ing an IRS Pseudonym. c. Ensuring that the IRS pseudonym is not used until notiﬁed that the request was approved by management or as a part of a resolution to IRS employee’s grievance and conﬁrmation is received from the PGLD/IM Office that the IRS pseudonym has been added to Outlook (email) and Discovery Directory. d. Following the procedures as outlined in IRM

, IRS Use Disapproved, if his or her initial IRS pseudonym request is not approved by his or her immediate manager. e. Using the approved IRS pseudonym in the performance of all official duties during his or her hours of work. f. Notifying his or her manager via either encrypted email, or hard copy in conﬁdential envelope, if he or she wishes to withdraw from the IRS Pseudonym Program. See IRM
, Withdrawing from the IRS Pseudonym Program. Note: IRS Employees must not open OS Ge
ervices tickets to request IRS pseudonyms.
10.5 Privacy and Information Protection

The PGLD Incident Management Office is responsible for: a. Managing the IRS Pseudonym Program in support of IRS employees who may, because of threats or potential threats to their personal need to work under the protection of an IRS pseudonym. b. Maintaining a copy of the encrypted email documenting the approval of request for an IRS pseudonym. e. Managing and maintaining the official Pseudonym Master List (PML) all other related ﬁles where IRS pseudonym information will be stored. f. Ensuring that all information pertaining to IRS pseudonym holders is maintained in a secure manner consistent with IRS security and privacy policy requirements. g. Updating HR Connect to add IRS employee’s IRS pseudonym informa- tion. h. Updating Outlook (email) and Discovery Directory to display the IRS pseudonym and initiating the process to change the Smar

D to the IRS pseudonym. i. Updating the PML each month to ensure that the information is correct and up-to-date. j. Processing all requests to withdraw from the IRS Pseudonym Program received by an IRS employee’s manager of record. See IRM
, Withdrawing from the IRS Pseudonym Program. Visit the Pseudonyms page in the Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base Site for additional information about the IRS Pseudonym Program.
The PGLD Incident Management Office is responsible for:
Note: Visit the Pseudonyms page in the Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Site for additional information about the IRS Pseudonym Program.

a. Submitting his or her request for an IRS pseudonym to his or her immediate manager via encrypted email, or hard copy in a conﬁdential envelope. b. Following all request requirements as outlined in IRM

, Request- ing an IRS Pseudonym. c. Ensuring that the IRS pseudonym is not used until notiﬁed that the request was approved by management or as a part of a resolution to the IRS employee’s grievance and conﬁrmation is received from the PGLD/IM Office that the IRS pseudonym has been added to Outlook (email) and Discovery Directory. d. Following the procedures as outlined in IRM

, IRS Pseudonym Use Disapproved, if his or her initial IRS pseudonym request is not approved by his or her immediate manager. e. Using the approved IRS pseudonym in the performance of all official duties during his or her hours of work. f. Notifying his or her manager via either encrypted email, or hard copy in conﬁdential envelope, if he or she wishes to withdraw from the IRS Pseudonym Program. See IRM
, Withdrawing from the IRS Pseudonym Program. IRS Employees must not open OS Ge
ervices tickets to request IRS
of Pseudonyms by IRS Employees 10.5.7
IRS Managers are responsible for: a. Reviewing requests for IRS pseudonyms to ensure all request require- ments as outlined in IRM

, Requesting an IRS Pseudonym, been addressed by the submitting IRS employee. b. Informing the IRS employee of approval or disapproval of the IRS pseudonym request within three business days of receipt. This can be done via encrypted email, or hard copy in a conﬁdential envelope. Method is at the manager’s discretion. c. Completing Form
, Manager’s Request for Processing and tration of IRS Pseudonym, if the IRS pseudonym request is approved the manager, and sending the Form

via encrypted email to IM’s *Pseudonym mailbox to process the request and register the IRS pseudonym. d. Instructing the IRS employee not to begin using the IRS pseudonym advised by the PGLD/IM Office that the change from his or her legal name to an IRS pseudonym has been made in Outlook (email) and covery Directory. e. Ensuring that the IRS employee’s co-workers, that is, IRS employees work in the same office building (excluding campuses), work unit, or stream, as appropriate, and the NTEU Chapter President, are notiﬁed a Bargaining Unit employee’s IRS pseudonym. f. Ensuring that the IRS pseudonym holder is referred to by his or her pseudonym during all regular job-related duties so that the IRS is not addressed or referred to by his or her legal name thereby his or her identity to taxpayers. g. Updating organizational listings of IRS employees to show only the pseudonym of the employee. h. Following the procedures as outlined in IRM

, IRS Use Disapproved, when not approving the IRS employee’s initial for an IRS pseudonym. i. Reviewing each of their employees’s IRS pseudonym holder status on annual basis. The manager must review their employee’s current work situation to determine if circumstances have changed since the IRS ployee originally obtained his or her IRS pseudonym. If the employee changed jobs or the situation prompting the original IRS pseudonym longer exists, the manager must advise the employee of the choice to withdraw from the program (withdrawal is totally voluntary). j. Sending an encrypted email to IM’s *Pseudonym mailbox upon receipt an IRS pseudonym holder’s request to withdraw from the program, that the IRS employee no longer requires an IRS pseudonym. See IRM
, Withdrawing from the IRS Pseudonym Program. k. Maintaining documentation of IRS pseudonym approval in the Performance File (EPF). IRS Managers must not open OS Ge

ervices tickets to request IRS pseudonyms. Program Reports: Statistics reﬂecting the number of new IRS pseudonym requests received and the time frame for completion, the number of als from the program, and the number of IRS pseudonym holders that have the IRS, are provided in all PGLD/IMEP Quarterly Operational Reviews. All formation is derived from the PML maintained by the PGLD/IM Office, as
IRS Managers are responsible for:
Program Reports: Statistics reﬂecting the number of new IRS pseudonym requests received and the time frame for completion, the number of withdraw
als from the program, and the number of IRS pseudonym holders that have left the IRS, are provided in all PGLD/IMEP Quarterly Operational Reviews. All in
formation is derived from the PML maintained by the PGLD/IM Office, as well
Privacy and Information as the Human Resources Reporting Center (HRRC) for veriﬁcation of those current IRS pseudonym holders who have left the IRS due to resignation, re- tirement or termination. (

) Program Effectiveness: Program goals are pseudonym processing within to ten business days after receipt of request and are measured via the infor- mation tracked and reported in the PGLD/IMEP Quarterly Operational Reviews. (
) Annual Review: IRS pseudonym policies and guidance included in this manual will be reviewed annually and any recommended changes will be submitted as needed. (

) The PGLD/IM Office maintains the centralized electronic listing of approved/ registered IRS pseudonym users known as the Pseudonym Master List Maintaining and storing the legal name and IRS pseudonym of an IRS employee is required to ensure it is an approved and registered IRS pseudonym. When employees no longer need an IRS pseudonym, change jobs, or leave the IRS, their names are removed from the ’active’ list and recorded as no longer in the IRS Pseudonym Program. The listing contains legal name, the chosen IRS pseudonym, the employee’s Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) and the date the IRS pseudonym was processed. It also contains the employee’s Post of Duty (POD), job title, email address and business unit. (

) Information from the listing is protected and access to the PML is not to anyone outside of the IRS Pseudonym Program manager and their Information from the PML is only shared with designated IRS employees veriﬁed need to know as determined by the PGLD/IM Office. This need to know would include: HRRC employees who need the information to maintain records for Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests; Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) agents for law enforcement and Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS) for identity tion before issuing new credentials in the IRS pseudonym. (
) The PML is included in the IRS system of records, General Personnel and Payroll Records, Treasury/IRS

, and must be treated accordingly for closure purposes. As such, the PGLD/IM Office will complete the required Privacy & Civil Liberties Impact Assessment (PCLIA) for the PML as well as System of Records Notice (SORN) that addresses the PII records contained the PML. (
) This subsection contains the deﬁnition of terms as used in the context of Section
of IRS RRA
) Pseudonym. A ﬁctitious name. (

) Protection of Personal Safety. Keeping one’s self, or others, from harm or danger. Reasons for concern for personal safety include: a. Verbal and written threats of bodily harm or injury from a taxpayer or or her representative directly involved in a case under review b. Actual bodily harm or injury from a taxpayer or his or her c. Harassment Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
U
10.5 Privacy and Information Protection
(08-13-2021) Terms/Deﬁnitions/ Acronyms
Protection of Personal Safety. Keeping one’s self, or others, from harm or danger. Reasons for concern for personal safety include:

Verbal and written threats of bodily harm or injury from a taxpayer or his or her representative directly involved in a case under review Actual bodily harm or injury from a taxpayer or his or her representative Harassment
of Pseudonyms by IRS Employees 10.5.7
Taxpayer or his or her representative contacts an employee or employ
ee’s family member at his or her home without purpose of legitimate communication Evidence of taxpayer or representative aggression towards any govern
ment employee Threatening or aggressive acts by a taxpayer or his or her representative towards any government employee

emotionally threatening activity, including, but not limited to: a. Committing battery against the employee, including unwanted touching b. Intimidating or attempting to intimidate the employee, such as with a show of weapons c. Uttering statements or speciﬁc threats of bodily harm directed to the employee d. Assaulting the employee e. Making statements threatening ﬁnancial harm to the employee f. Harassing the employee g. Contacting the employee at his or her home h. Committing the acts listed above against members of the employee’s family i. Committing the acts listed above against another employee and the re- questing employee has been assigned a case involving the same taxpayer (

) Adequate Justiﬁcation - Risk to Personal Safety. Adequate justiﬁcation is also deﬁned as situations in which an employee’s job or place of duty poses an increased risk to personal safety to themselves or their families. This increased risk may be due to, but not limited to, any of the following: a. A locator service shows the taxpayer, whose case the employee has been assigned, has a violent criminal history that would suggest a ened risk of harassment towards an employee. b. The employee is expected to encounter taxpayers or representatives are active members of groups that advocate violence against the IRS other federal employees. c. The employee is expected to encounter taxpayers who have been reported to have engaged in activities that physically, ﬁnancially, or tionally threaten or harm any other federal, state, county, or local government employee. (

) Documentation of Credible Evidence. Documentation of credible includes, but is not limited to, the examples listed below: a. A signed statement by an employee, family member(s) or witness, or letter signed by the taxpayer or his or her representative, which strates any of the criteria listed under Adequate Justiﬁcation. Internal Revenue Manual

a. A locator service shows the taxpayer, whose case the employee has been assigned, has a violent criminal history that would suggest a height

ened risk of harassment towards an employee. b. The employee is expected to encounter taxpayers or representatives are active members of groups that advocate violence against the IRS or other federal employees. c. The employee is expected to encounter taxpayers who have been reported to have engaged in activities that physically, ﬁnancially, or emo
tionally threaten or harm any other federal, state, county, or local government employee.
A signed statement by an employee, family member(s) or witness, or a letter signed by the taxpayer or his or her representative, which strates any of the criteria listed under Adequate Justiﬁcation.

A document from a ﬁnancial institution showing that a taxpayer has tried to place liens on an employee’s assets.

, Physical Security Program, Identiﬁcation Media. IRM

applies to the control, issuance and disposition of Identiﬁcation (ID) media. ID media are authorized forms of ID that are designed to provide evidence of the bearer’s identity, authorization to access IRS cilities or systems, or authority to act as an agent of the IRS in the performance of official duties. b. provides policies, authorities, directives, and responsibilities for Civil Enforcement and Non-Enforcement Pocket Commissions (PC). It applies to the control, issuance, and destruction of a PC. (

The IRS is committed to the personal safety of its employees. This IRM explains the steps needed to acquire an IRS pseudonym to ensure IRS employees have the necessary protection to their personal safety and the pre- vention of harm or danger to themselves and their families. This IRM provides information, guidance, and procedures for all IRS managers and employees on the use of IRS pseudonyms by IRS employees in compli- ance with Section
of IRS RRA
and contains information from the
This IRM provides information, guidance, and procedures for all IRS managers and employees on the use of IRS pseudonyms by IRS employees in compli- ance with Section
of IRS RRA
and contains information from the Pseudonym Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed by the IRS and
10.5 Privacy and Information Protection
) Section
of IRS RRA

authorizes the use of pseudonyms by IRS employees. Listed below are some of the guidelines, requirements and tions of having an IRS pseudonym: a. IRS employees who used IRS pseudonyms before the enactment of Section
were “grandfathered” in under the statute. b. Section
authorizes the use of pseudonyms by IRS employees if adequate justiﬁcation is provided by the employee and its use is approved by the employee’s manager. c. Prior to Section

, the use of pseudonyms by IRS employees was permitted if the employee believed he or she could be identiﬁed by his her last name so as to warrant the use of an IRS pseudonym. No gerial approval was required. It was only required that the IRS pseudonym be registered with the employee’s manager. d. Section

is meant to eliminate the taxpayer perception that IRS employees avoid accountability for their actions through the use of pseudonyms, while still protecting an employee’s right to use IRS onyms in appropriate circumstances. e. The IRS employee’s manager must approve use of the IRS prior to its use. Requests to use IRS pseudonyms that do not provide adequate justiﬁcation will be denied on that basis. f. See Exhibit
, Verbatim Text of Section
of IRS RRA
USC
, dated July
, for the text of Section
of IRS RRA
from
USC
) Any taxpayer-speciﬁc information submitted to justify the request for an IRS pseudonym remains the return information of the taxpayer and must be protected under the provisions of IRC

material. Designated Material (
) The procedures in this section must be used by IRS employees to request IRS pseudonym and by IRS managers to approve the use of IRS an IRS by IRS employees. (
) IRS employees who believe that using an IRS pseudonym is necessary submit the pseudonym request to their immediate manager via encrypted email, or hard copy in a conﬁdential envelope. (
) IRS employees requesting an IRS pseudonym must provide adequate tion for the use of an IRS pseudonym related to the protection of personal safety as described in (
) and (

) IRS employee requests for the use of an IRS pseudonym must include the pseudonym that the employee chooses to use. IRS employees must use following guidance when choosing an IRS pseudonym. The requested pseudonym must: a. Be easy to remember and a name with which the employee is able. b. Use the employee’s legal ﬁrst name unless it’s so unique that it mises the employee’s identity, in which case a ﬁrst name may also be chosen. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Any taxpayer-speciﬁc information submitted to justify the request for an IRS pseudonym remains the return information of the taxpayer and must be protected under the provisions of IRC
Any return information included with the application must be speciﬁcally designated as IRC
material. (
) The procedures in this section must be used by IRS employees to request an IRS pseudonym and by IRS managers to approve the use of IRS by IRS employees. (
) IRS employees who believe that using an IRS pseudonym is necessary must submit the pseudonym request to their immediate manager via encrypted email, or hard copy in a conﬁdential envelope. (

) IRS employee requests for the use of an IRS pseudonym must include the pseudonym that the employee chooses to use. IRS employees must use the following guidance when choosing an IRS pseudonym. The requested pseudonym must: a. Be easy to remember and a name with which the employee is comfort- able. b. Use the employee’s legal ﬁrst name unless it’s so unique that it compro- mises the employee’s identity, in which case a ﬁrst name may also be chosen.

c. Use a common surname (last name) different from the employee’s legal surname. Names previously used by the employee, such as birth maiden names, names from prior marriages, or previously used legal names, must not be used as IRS pseudonyms as these do not ad

equately protect an employee’s identity as they could be traced back to the IRS employee thereby compromising his or her safety and security. d. Not be the name of someone famous, a character, or a product.

) IRS employees who receive an approved IRS pseudonym are not to use the pseudonym until notiﬁed that the request was approved by ment or as a part of a resolution to the employee’s grievance. ) IRS employees who receive an approved IRS pseudonym must use it in the performance of all official duties during his or her hours of work. The IRS pseudonym is only for work purposes and conducting official duties, interacting with taxpayers. An IRS pseudonym must never be used for personal business or when off duty. (

) If an IRS pseudonym is compromised, the employee can request a replace- ment pseudonym without the need for establishing adequate justiﬁcation, as approval was previously given by the appropriate manager. (

) Field Operation Employees. A request for an IRS pseudonym made by IRS employee in Field Operations who has regular face-to-face contact with taxpayers will normally be presumed to have satisﬁed adequate justiﬁcation deﬁned by the term, Adequate Justiﬁcation, in IRM

, Terms/ Deﬁnitions/Acronyms, when those employees have personal safety and one of the following applies: a. The ﬁeld employee has been assigned cases in high risk geographic areas, for example, remote areas with limited cell phone access, ﬁeld calls to correctional facilities, historically high crime areas, etc. b. The ﬁeld employee perceives that his or her safety or the safety of his her family is at risk. c. The ﬁeld employee is assigned to a case or is assisting an employee is assigned a case where either the history of the case indicates a concern or the taxpayer(s) involved have been coded either Potentially Dangerous Taxpayer (PDT) or Caution Upon Contact (CAU). Documentation of IRS pseudonym approval will be maintained in the EPF for as long as the employee is using the IRS pseudonym.
Privacy and Information (
) If the manager approves the IRS employee’s request for the use of an IRS pseudonym, the manager will complete Form
, Manager’s Request for Use Processing and Registration of IRS Pseudonym. Once completed, the manager will send the Form
via encrypted email to IM’s *Pseudonym mailbox to register the pseudonym with the PGLD/IM Office. (
) Once the Form

is received, the PGLD/IM Office will: a. Review the request to ensure adequate justiﬁcation has been met. b. Add the employee to the Pseudonym Master List (PML). c. Update HR Connect to add the employee’s IRS pseudonym d. Update Outlook (email) and Discovery Directory to display the IRS pseudonym. e. Initiate the process to change the Smar
D to the IRS pseudonym. (

) Within three business days from receipt of the request, the manager will the employee that the IRS pseudonym request is approved with instructions that the employee must not begin using the IRS pseudonym until advised the PGLD/IM Office that the change from the employee’s legal name to an pseudonym has been made within Outlook (email) and Discovery Directory. (

) Once an employee begins using his or her IRS pseudonym, the employee’s manager will promptly take steps to ensure that the employee’s co-workers, that is, IRS employees that work in the same office building (excluding campuses), work unit, or work stream, as appropriate, and the NTEU President are notiﬁed of the Bargaining Unit employee’s IRS pseudonym so that the employee is not addressed or referred to by his or her legal name, thereby revealing his or her identity to taxpayers. Organizational listings of employees must also be updated to show only the IRS pseudonym. (

) Once an employee begins using his or her IRS pseudonym, the employee must change his or her voice mail message to include his or her IRS pseudonym and, if warranted, the name on his or her cubicle, office, etc. (
) An IRS pseudonym stays with an employee for the duration of his or her career or until the employee determines he or she no longer requires one. IRM
, Withdrawing from the IRS Pseudonym Program, for on how to withdraw from the IRS Pseudonym Program. (

) If the manager disapproves the IRS employee’s request for the use of an pseudonym, within three business days from receipt of the request, the Use manager must return the request to the employee for additional justiﬁcation. The manager must provide, in writing, the reason(s) for disapproval. The manager must also advise the employee, in writing, that he or she has the right, within ﬁve business days, excluding absences from work, to provide tional justiﬁcation or information in support of his or her request via email or hard copy in a conﬁdential envelope. (

) The employee has ﬁve business days from receipt of the disapproval, excluding absences from work, to provide additional written justiﬁcation or formation to his or her manager in support of his or her request for the use an IRS pseudonym. (
) Upon receipt of the additional justiﬁcation, the manager has three business days to review the request.

) If the manager disapproves the request a second time, he or she will return the request to the employee, and provide, in writing, the reason(s) for disap- proval. The manager will provide the name and contact information for the level manager and advise the employee that they have the option, within business days, excluding absences from work, to appeal the disapproval to elevate his or her request to the next level of management. (
) The employee has three business days, excluding absences from work, to appeal the disapproval to the appropriate next level manager. (

) If the employee appeals the disapproval, the next level manager has three business days to review the request and approve or disapprove it. If disap- proved at this level, the employee may ﬁle a grievance under the terms of Article
, Employee Grievance, of the National Agreement for bargaining employees, Document
, or use IRS grievance procedures for non- bargaining unit employees. (

Managers will ensure that the IRS employee’s co-workers, that is, IRS employees that work in the same office building (excluding campuses), work unit, or work stream, as appropriate, and the NTEU Chapter dent are notiﬁed that the IRS pseudonym is no longer in use. ervices tickets to withdraw the IRS Pseudonym Program. An employee must submit his or her quest for withdrawal through his or her manager to IM’s *Pseudonym mailbox.

(02-26-2021) Withdrawing from the IRS Pseudonym Program

An IRS employee with an approved IRS pseudonym may withdraw from the program at any time. When an employee no longer desires an IRS pseudonym, the employee must notify his or her manager via either encrypted email or hard copy in a conﬁdential envelope. If the manager receives such notiﬁcation, or when the IRS pseudonym holder separates from the IRS, the manager must send an encrypted email to IM’s *Pseudonym mailbox stating that the employee no longer requires an IRS pseudonym. The manager must include the employee’s legal name, the employee’s assigned IRS pseudonym, the employee’s SEID, the employee’s date of birth (required for Smar

D sponsorship) and the reason for withdrawal from the IRS Pseudonym Program. If ap- plicable, the manager must also ensure the Pocket Commission issued the IRS pseudonym is recovered and take the necessary steps to re- quest a new PC in the employee’s legal name. The PGLD/IM Office will take the necessary steps to remove the ee’s IRS pseudonym records from the PML; change the IRS pseudonym back to the employee’s legal name on Outlook (email) and Discovery Di- rectory; and initiate the process of changing the Smar

D back to the le- gal name. Managers will ensure that the IRS employee’s co-workers, that is, IRS employees that work in the same office building (excluding campuses), work unit, or work stream, as appropriate, and the NTEU Chapter Presi- dent are notiﬁed that the IRS pseudonym is no longer in use.

provides identiﬁcation requirements for all employees (including IRS pseudonym holders) working tax related matters. (

In addition, a telephone required on all taxpayer correspondence. This will provide taxpayers with enough information to identify an IRS employee who may have previously assisted with tax related matters. (

If an IDRS/unique letter system number is not generated, use of an employee’s unique identifying number is required. (

) While reviewing taxpayer correspondence and observing employee or in-person contacts with taxpayers or taxpayers’ representatives, must ensure that the employee name (approved IRS pseudonym) and generated IDRS/unique letter system number, or Smar
D Card number, are properly used. (

) When attempting to locate a speciﬁc IRS employee at the insistence of the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative, managers must ensure that only approved IRS pseudonym used by the IRS employee is disclosed.

) Sworn documents and/or any other document ﬁled with any court, but not limited to, affidavits used in connection with enforcing summonses obtaining writs of entry, may only be signed with the approved IRS if the document states that it is signed using an IRS pseudonym. Absent a statement, the document must be signed using the declarant’s legal and must be ﬁled with the court as a sealed document. (

) IRS employees who use an approved IRS pseudonym must use it for all business, including email. The only exceptions are pertinent personnel for example, payroll. See IRM
for additional examples of pertinent personnel matters. (

) Once the IRS employee begins using the approved IRS pseudonym, the manager must ensure that the employee’s co-workers and associates are informed of the IRS pseudonym, and explain that all employees must use IRS pseudonym when speaking of, or to, the employee. (
) Managers of IRS pseudonym holders must ensure that office documents including team listings, organization charts, and telephone directories are updated to reﬂect each employee’s IRS pseudonym. (
) Managers and employees who work with an IRS pseudonym holder must never reveal the legal name of the IRS pseudonym holder to anyone or externally. (
) Managers and employees who work with an IRS pseudonym holder must introduce the IRS pseudonym holder by the IRS pseudonym, not his or her legal name, in all situations. (
) Managers must inform the local NTEU Chapter President of a Bargaining employee’s IRS pseudonym. (

) A Travel Card is a credit card used to pay for authorized official IRS travel allowable travel related expenses. Each Travel Card reﬂects an individual″ account established in the Travel Cardholder’s name. The term individually ″ billed is synonymous with Travel Card, Credit Card, government issued Card, and IBA. (
) IRS pseudonym holders may apply for a government Travel Card in their name or IRS pseudonym. (
) IRS pseudonym holders are required to use their legal name when airline tickets with their government Travel Card. (

) During the government Travel Card application process, if applying using IRS pseudonym, IRS pseudonym holders MUST NOT CONSENT to the check to avoid any potential connection to their legal name via their personal credit report. a. IRS pseudonym holders must send an email to IM’s *Pseudonym indicating that they have applied for and received their government Card in their IRS pseudonym. Employees must provide the following formation in the email: IRS pseudonym; SEID; and date card issued. b. The PGLD/IM Office will then notify CFO Credit Card Services to any restrictions on the Travel Card that may result from not consenting the credit check. (

) The government Travel Card in the IRS pseudonym can be used for all travel, including IRS approved funding for travel expenses of IRS employees performing NTEU business. In such cases, IRS pseudonym holders are still required to comply with the Government bank card provisions regarding priate use and timely payments. If the IRS does not approve funding for expenses of IRS employees performing NTEU business, the Travel Card Internal Revenue Manual

) Just as IRS employees with IRS pseudonyms must use their IRS for all official purposes, all IRS employees and managers must correspond With converse with, or about, IRS pseudonym employees using only the IRS pseudonym. The only exceptions are pertinent personnel matters (for example, payroll). (

) IRS employee lists, including email distribution lists, to, or about, IRS pseudonym employees, must include IRS pseudonyms rather than employee legal names. Otherwise, IRS pseudonym holders’ legal identities could ulti- mately be compromised. (
) Written correspondence, including an IRS pseudonym holder’s IRS and legal name, must be protected. Email including such information must encrypted. (

) All IRS systems (except Discovery Directory and Outlook) contain legal Employees with approved pseudonyms must use their legal names when signing internal personnel documents such as evaluations, telework agree- ments, UNAX forms and alternative work schedule agreements. Other personnel matters for which IRS pseudonym holders must use their legal include payroll, beneﬁts, separating employee clearances and other issues. (

) To ensure, other than for pertinent personnel matters, IRS pseudonyms are properly used by all IRS employees, employee name lists and distribution groups must be acquired from Discovery Directory only. Information acquired from personnel systems such as HR Connect, SETR/TAPS, and TIMIS, legal names and the use of these personnel systems could compromise the identity of an IRS pseudonym holder. (

) IRS employees have a responsibility to use care to protect the identity of co-workers with IRS pseudonyms. It is critical that the IRS pseudonym is the only name disclosed when referencing the employee during all with taxpayers or their representatives. (
) Any written correspondence including an IRS pseudonym holder’s IRS pseudonym and legal name must be protected. Email including such tion must be encrypted.

USE OF PSEUDONYMS BY INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE EMPLOYEES
Public Law 105-206, Title III, Sec. 3706, July 22, 1998, 112 Stat. 778, provided that:
a. In General. - Any employee of the Internal Revenue Service may use a pseudonym only if -
adequate justiﬁcation for the use of a pseudonym is provided by the employee, including tion of personal safety; and
such use is approved by the employee’s supervisor before the pseudonym is used. b. Effective Date. - Subsection (a) shall apply to requests made after the date of the enactment of this Act [July
